context: Occupational levels of airborne sulfur bearing compounds and estimated health effects upon exposure are submitted especially in industrial air pollution studies. Air composition around foully smelling piggeries and manure storage houses as sources of odorous organic sulfur compounds has also been studied. Clanton et al. (1999) found maximum 0.05 mgm−3 methane thiol, 0.112 mgm−3 dimethylsulfide and 3.92 mgm−3 H2S concentrations in air samples taken from a manure storage area. In this study that included 20 sulfur-containing compounds, only H2S, carbonyl sulfide, methane thiol, dimethylsulfide, carbon disulfide and dimethyldisulfide could be detected in the air samples. In addition to air samples, isopropane thiol was found in liquid samples taken from the manure area. More recently, biogenic emission data from the seas (Kouvarakis and Mihailopoulos, 2002) and from the wetlands (Watts, 2000) have been added to further enlarge the wide range of studies on organic sulfur compounds literature. Atmospheric conversion of sulfur bearing organic molecules into sulfur oxides and then to sulfates is an important mechanism in secondary particulate matter formation (Seinfeld and Pandis, 1998).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, methylsulfanylmethane is mentioned as one of the sulfur-bearing compounds present in the air around industrial sources, particularly in relation to odorous organic sulfur compounds. Sulfhydryl compounds, which include various sulfur-containing organic molecules, are relevant here as they encompass methylsulfanylmethane. The study highlights the presence of multiple sulfur compounds in the environment, indicating a broader category that includes methylsulfanylmethane as a specific example of sulfhydryl compounds.
